material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: Taking into account the fact that both IDT and NT are comparatively rigid coplanar structures along the polymer backbone , the IDT-NT based polymers may suffer solubility issue since the tetraoctylbenzene groups attached to the carbon bridges of IDT unit would not be enough to guarantee their solubility in common organic solvents. Therefore , the spacers consist of thiophene or bithiophene functionalized with various alkyl side chains were introduced in between IDT and NT units to improve the solubility of the resulting polymers , which may also potentially lead to improved molecular weight that is favorable for the optimal morphology and charge carrier transport. 39-41 We notice that the incorporated side chains may also increase the dihedral angle of their contiguous aromatic units , 42,43 which may somewhat inhibit polymer backbone planarity and thereby increase band gap and lower the charge carrier mobility. 40,41 However , it should be tried several different alkyl side chains to achieve a delicate balance of the molecular weight , solubility as well as planarity of polymers as no comprehensive rule has yet emerged of the influences of specific side chains. 44,45 It was realized that by switching the spacer between the IDT and NT units , the processability , backbone planarity , charge carrier mobility and film morphology can be optimized. Further investigation of photovoltaic performances indicates all devices present high V oc because of the relatively deep HOMO energy levels of these polymers , and the highest PCE of 5.05% was achieved based on PIDT-C12NT . Differential scanning calorimetry ( DSC ) and thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ; see Figure 1 ) were used to probe thermal properties. No phase transition was observed for all three polymers by DSC analysis up to 300 ° C. All polymers have decomposition temperature ( defined as the 5% weight - loss temperature , T d ) over 450 °C under nitrogen as determined by TGA analysis , indicating their excellent thermal stabilities. Optical and Electrochemical Properties. The UV - vis absorption spectra of all polymers in both chlorobenzene solution ( 1 × 10^-3 mg mL -1 ) and as thin films ( spin - casted from chlorobenzene solutions with concentration of 8 mg mL -1 ) are shown in Figure 2. All three polymers exhibit dual characteristic absorption bands , where the short wavelength absorbance originated from the π-π* transition of the IDT unit , while the long wavelength absorbance could be ascribed to the intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) between the IDT and the NT segments. 27 In chlorobenzene ( CB ) solution , PIDT - EHNT showed an absorption maximum at 599 nm and a slightly weaker peak at 433 nm ; when changing the branched 2ethylhexyl to linear hexyl side chain , the resulted polymer PIDT - DTNT showed a slightly bathochromic shift of two corresponding peaks to 608 and 439 nm , respectively , which may due to the reduced steric hindrance of the linear side chain.

Let's think step by step.

1. Materials mentioned:
* PIDT-C12NT (polymer with IDT and NT units and a spacer)
* PIDT-EHNT (polymer with IDT and NT units and a spacer with a branched 2-ethylhexyl side chain)
* PIDT-DTNT (polymer with IDT and NT units and a spacer with a linear hexyl side chain)
* IDT (indole-dithiophene)
* NT (naphthalene-thiophene)
* Tetraoctylbenzene
* Thiophene
* Bithiophene
* Alkyl side chains (2-ethylhexyl and hexyl)
2. Properties mentioned:
* Solubility
* Molecular weight
* Planarity
* Charge carrier mobility
* Band gap
* Photovoltaic performances (Voc, PCE)
* Thermal properties (decomposition temperature, Td)
* Optical properties (UV-vis absorption spectra)
3. Numerical values mentioned:
* 39-41 (number of articles cited for the effect of spacers on solubility)
* 40, 41 (number of articles cited for the effect of spacers on planarity and charge carrier mobility)
* 42, 43 (number of articles cited for the effect of side chains on dihedral angle and planarity)
* 44, 45 (number of articles cited for the effect of side chains on molecular weight and solubility)
* 5% (weight loss temperature, Td, of all polymers)
* 450°C (decomposition temperature of all polymers)
* 300°C (temperature limit for DSC analysis)
* 1 × 10^-3 mg mL-1 (concentration of polymer solutions in chlorobenzene)
* 8 mg mL-1 (concentration of polymer solutions in chlorobenzene for thin film deposition)
* 599 nm and 433 nm (absorption maxima of PIDT-EHNT in chlorobenzene solution)
* 608 nm and 439 nm (absorption maxima of PIDT-DTNT in chlorobenzene solution)
* 5.05% (highest PCE of PIDT-C12NT)
4. Summary of properties and numerical values:
* PIDT-C12NT, PIDT-EHNT, and PIDT-DTNT are polymers with IDT and NT units and a spacer, which affects their solubility, molecular weight, planarity, charge carrier mobility, and photovoltaic performances.
* The spacer can improve solubility but may also affect planarity and charge carrier mobility.
* The incorporated side chains may increase the dihedral angle of the contiguous aromatic units and somewhat inhibit polymer backbone planarity, which may affect charge carrier mobility.
* All three polymers have excellent thermal stability with a decomposition temperature over 450°C.
* The UV-vis absorption spectra of the polymers in chlorobenzene solution and as thin films show dual characteristic absorption bands, indicating π-π* transition of the IDT unit and intramolecular charge transfer between the IDT and NT segments.
* The bathochromic shift of the absorption peaks in PIDT-DTNT suggests reduced steric hindrance of the linear side chain.
* PIDT-C12NT shows the highest PCE of 5.05%.

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

| Material Name | Material Property | Material Property (Abbr.) | Numerical Value | Condition |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| PIDT-C12NT | Photovoltaic performance | PCE | 5.05% | Highest among the three polymers |
| PIDT-EHNT | Solubility | - | 1 × 10^-3 mg mL-1 | Improved by introducing spacer |
| PIDT-DTNT | Planarity | - | - | Slightly affected by side chain length |
| PIDT-DTNT | Charge carrier mobility | - | - | Slightly affected by side chain length |
| All polymers | Thermal stability | Td | 450°C | Excellent thermal stability |
| All polymers | UV-vis absorption spectra | - | 599 nm, 433 nm (PIDT-EHNT) | Dual characteristic absorption bands |

Note: The table only includes the properties and numerical values mentioned in the original paragraph.
